placesVisited: Paro, Drukgyal Dzong, View of Mt. Jhomolhari (7,314 m), Kichu Lhakhang, Taktsang monastery, National Memorial Chorten, Thimphu, Dochula pass, Punakha, Hike to Khamsung Yulley Namgyal Choling Monastery, Gangtey, Wangdiphodrang, Black necked cranes, Trongsa, Bumthang
generalInfo:
Embark on a trans-formative journey through Bhutan's pristine landscapes and rich cultural tapestry with a luxury tour encompassing Thimphu, Paro, Punakha, Gangtey, and Bumthang. You will see as much of the breathtaking country as you can in just one week, and your journey will begin by flying first class on Druk Air/ Bhutan Airlines to Paro, where your guide and driver will greet you. Your tour will start after checking into your accommodation.
First-class accommodation on this trip includes Le Méridien in Thimphu, Uma Resort in Punakha, Gangtey Lodge in Gangtey, Six Senses in Bumthang, and Le Méridien in Paro which offers the perfect basis for trips into Bhutan’s sacred heartland.
Feel free to discuss add-on services so that we can create the perfect, bespoke Bhutan trip for you.

dayInfo.description: Spend the morning visiting some of the highlights of the capital, including one of the oldest temples in Thimphu, 12th-century Changangkha Lhakhang, and the National Memorial Chorten, first initiated by the Third King and completed by Queen Mother in memory of the third King who passed away in 1972. Afterward visit Simply Bhutan, a living museum where you will be introduced to seven sections of programs including cultural programs. After lunch transfer to Punakha, the ancient capital of Bhutan. Overnight and dinner in Uma Resort Punakha

After breakfast, visit Punakha Dzong, the “Palace of Great Happiness” built in 1637 by the Zhabdrung, the ‘Unifier of Bhutan’. It is situated at the confluence of the Pho Chu and Mo Chu (Male and Female rivers) and is the winter headquarters of the Je Khenpo and hundreds of monks who move en masse from Thimphu to this warmer location. The three-story main temple of the Punakha Dzong is a breathtaking example of traditional architecture with four intricately embossed entrance pillars crafted from cypress and decorated in gold and silver. It was here in 1907 that Bhutan’s first king was crowned. Afterward, transfer to Phobjikha Valley (5.5-6 hours). The drive takes you through the countryside and affords a glimpse of everyday life in this most remote Himalayan kingdom. Continue through the market town of Wangduephodrang, and up winding mountain roads through mixed forests and over high passes before descending into the wide and picturesque Phobjikha Valley. Phobjikha is one of Bhutan’s few glacial valleys, and chosen winter home of black-necked cranes (November – March) migrating from the Tibetan plateau. Dinner, and overnight at Gangtey Lodge.

Following breakfast visit Phobjikha Black Necked Crane Center which is situated on the edge of the forest and wetland along the main road of Phobjikha Valley has an observation room equipped with high power telescope and spotting scopes for catching the best view of the cranes. Cranes in Bhutan are winter visitors from late October to mid-February. Star of the center is Karma, an injured black-necked crane who was discovered as an eight-month-old with a broken wing and now lives in a neighboring enclosure. Afterward, visit Gangtey Gompa, dating back to the 16th century. Move towards Bumthang via Pele La pass (3,420m) on the Black Mountain range towards Trongsa (4.5 hours). The pass takes over Black Mountain, the boundary between Western and Central Bhutan. En route visit beautiful 18th-century Chendebji chorten. Trongsa is the ancestral home of Bhutan’s ruling dynasty. Visit Trongsa Dzong, the largest Dzong in Bhutan, and the Ta Dzong Museum housing a collection of historical artifacts of the Royal Family. Continue driving towards Bumthang (2.5 hours), the spiritual of the kingdom. Bumthang is home to some of Bhutan’s oldest Palaces, Buddhist temples, and monasteries. On arrival transfer to your hotel. Enjoy an optional Spa Treatment before dinner. Overnight at Six Senses in Bumthang.

In the morning after breakfast, visit Kurjey Lhakhang, one of the most sacred places in the kingdom where Bhutan’s patron saint Guru Rinpoche meditated and 7th century Jambay Lhakhang. It dates back to the origins of Buddhism in Bhutan and is one of the kingdom's oldest temples. Return to your hotel for lunch or you can also choose to eat at the DoT (Department of Tourism) approved restaurant before continuing sightseeing including Jakar Dzong, and Tamshing Lhakhang, founded in 1501 by Pema Lingpa containing interesting and ancient Buddhist wall paintings. Overnight in Six Senses in Bumthang.

Enjoy a stunning mountain flight with incredible views over Bhutan from Bumthang back to the Paro Valley or you can choose to return by car. (Druk Air domestic flights are available only on Thursday & Sunday) On arrival, you will enjoy some sightseeing around Paro including a visit to the Ta Dzong Museum housing many religious relics, works of art, and handicrafts offering a great orientation into Bhutan’s historical, cultural, and religious past. Next, visit the Rinpung Dzong to see the painting of the great saint Milarepa, considered the master of meditation by the Bhutanese and believed to have attained enlightenment in a lifetime. Dzong's are fortresses where most of them house district administrative offices, which were once strategic forts. Afterward, check-in and dinner at Le Méridien Paro.

You will drive to Ramthangkha after breakfast, where your guide will get your entry ticket. For physically healthy individuals, the Taktsang hike takes around two hours each way. For those who have trouble walking, there is a pony ride to the halfway point, which costs about $35 one way or you can choose to walk which will take you around seven hours altogether. Remember it is worth it. The view of Taktsang Monastery built on a sheer cliff face 900 meters above the valley floor is a spectacular sight. The Monastery is also an important pilgrim site for the Buddhists. The great Guru Rinpoche is said to have flown here on the back of a tigress (Yeshey Tshogyal ) when he brought the teachings of the Buddhist Dharma to Bhutan in the 8th Century. He then mediated in a cave there for 3 years, 3 months, 3 weeks, and 3 days where the monastery was later built. Refreshments and lunch will be arranged in the cafeteria. If time permits, you can visit 7th Century Kyichu Lhakhang, one of the 108 temples constructed by the Tibetan king Songtsen Gampo. Dinner and overnight at Le Méridien Paro.
After breakfast at your hotel, a guide and driver will drop you at the airport for a flight to your onward destination.
